Pros:

Beautiful anime-inspired character designs with lots of variety.

Very beginner-friendly—progress feels rewarding at the start.

Idle system works well, so you can make progress even when offline.

Plenty of content: campaigns, arena battles, and events keep it from being too empty.

Cons:

Heavy reliance on gacha mechanics—you’ll need luck (or money) to get top-tier heroes.

Can feel repetitive after a while since the gameplay loop is pretty standard for idle RPGs.

Balance issues: some characters are way stronger than others.

Microtransactions are very present, which might be frustrating if you want to stay free-to-play.

Overall:
Angel Legion is a solid idle RPG if you enjoy collecting heroes and watching them auto-battle while you manage upgrades. It’s stylish, has nice visuals, and offers a lot of activities, but the grind and gacha system can test your patience. Good for casual play, but not something to dive into expecting deep, strategic gameplay.

Angel Legion — Style, squads, and a surprising amount of depth

TL;DR: Flashy visuals, striking heroine designs, and snappy, effects-heavy battles. Lots of modes and build paths keep the grind from going stale. Monetization exists (it’s a gacha), but the game gives you enough levers to tinker and progress if you’re patient.

Visuals & Performance

Angel Legion looks slick. Menus pop, skill cuts are crisp, and battle VFX land with satisfying punch without choking the screen. On a mid-range rig it runs smoothly; animations are clean enough to make auto-grind watchable instead of a chore. It won’t rival AAA art budgets, but for an anime-styled squad RPG, the polish is legit.

The Women (Character Design & Customization)

Let’s be honest: the heroines are the headline. Designs range from elegant to dangerously extra, with good model work, distinct silhouettes, and flashy ultimates. Skins change the vibe meaningfully rather than just palette-swapping. Beyond eye-candy, each character’s kit actually nudges you toward different team comps—DPS nukers, sustain supports, debuff queens, and weird utility picks that reward experimentation.

Combat (Fast, punchy, and readable)

Battles are quick and kinetic. Timing your ult chains and buff windows matters, and the game rewards synergy over raw power. Boss fights toss in mechanics that make you care about turn order, shields, and cleanse timing. Auto works for dailies, but manual play is where you squeeze out those clutch clears.

Endless Variety: “Do X things” (and then ten more)

If you like feeling busy in a good way, this delivers. You can:

Build: level, ascend, gear, rune/gene/skill trees, and link bonuses—multiple layers to min-max.

Teamcraft: faction buffs, role coverage, speed tuning, counter comps.

Climb: campaign, elite stages, boss towers, time-limited events, PvP ladders.

Farm: resource raids, gear dungeons, daily trials with rotating modifiers.

Tinker: artifacts, loadouts, and situational builds for specific bosses.
There’s always one more upgrade path to push, which keeps the loop lively.

QoL & Grind

Daily routes are streamlined, with sensible auto-clear options and skip tokens to cut the time sink. The grind is real (it’s the genre), but checklists are tight enough that you can log in, bang out essentials, and log off without feeling trapped.

Monetization

Gacha pulls and costumes exist. If you’re free-to-play, expect a slower climb—but smart team synergy, event rewards, and targeted farming can carry you further than you’d think. Whales will whale; everyone else can still progress.

Verdict

If you’re here for striking heroines, crisp anime aesthetics, and fast tactical battles—with a buffet of modes and build systems to tinker with—Angel Legion is an easy recommend. It’s stylish, it’s punchy, and it gives theorycrafters plenty to chew on.

Score: 8/10 — “Come for the angels, stay for the team-building.”

Short blurb (for the summary line):
Flashy anime visuals, top-tier heroine designs, and snappy battles wrapped in a mode-rich grind that rewards smart teamcraft. Gacha caveats apply, fun still wins.

You start up as a faceless commander who wakes up your first of these companions (and it appears the only one you really interact with outside of combat, beyond tapping others in their body) who trains this advanced android to take part in hunting down bandits that defy the galactic authority.

You can gain more androids and grow them in these pods because they are more like the character Melfina from Outlaw Star being a mixture of artifical and organic to create these androids that are made for combat, yet all look like beauty models that would fit better in a world with acting or modelling.

All of them look very familiar and the animated scenes you see feel like AI, though I have no idea if they really are or not, but they just have that same style as those many AI dating apps that YouTube likes to bombard you with so it's hard not to see them as being related.

The gameplay, just like so many, is essentially auto-play just like Hero Wars, Raid: Shadow Legends and so damn many others out there, making it so that even if you have a more tactical mind, you will do as well as anyone else with the exact same stats of characters and such. +/- RNG of course.

I enjoyed flying the space ship around and the ability to skip the combat against groups of level 1 robot mobs to get the loot, though the equipment was a pain in the ass to deal with because of how, just like other games I've played in the past, you have all these qualities and what makes it more confusing is that the stats are not always the same, even if it's the same type of equipment. One piece of Soldier Breastplate might give +3.00% attack, but another will give you +1 Damage resistance and you need these sets to be matching because you gain passive buffs for doing this.

Now, here's where you think a major selling point of this game might be as it advertises itself as an adult game and after Eros Fantasy I was expecting actual nudity, however, because of where this game comes from (China) you instead have a white haze that covers her body, as if she's wearing a dress of solid light! This game bills itself as an "Idle" game. The desktop shortcut is titled, "Angle Legion LSP Idle RPG", after all. However don't be fooled, it's just another GACHA game, so I'll break this up into a couple of sections.

Combat:
Combat is limited to 20 turns. If you don't defeat all the enemies by the end of turn 20 you auto-lose. This is a mechanic that limits your advancement since you only gain resources from winning. The only exceptions are "Arena" matches where you gain participation currency. If you win you get more of that currency and usually some other currencies as well. Your characters can do a normal attack on every turn unless they are affected by sleep, stun, petrification, or dead. Normal attacks also increase energy by 2 points unless the character is affected by insulation. Unless affected by silence, when a character has at least 4 energy they can use a special attack that will do extra damage, may attack multiple enemies, and my apply status effects like stun, blind, silence, insulation, petrification, etc..

Leveling:
You're characters don't level through experience, you have to spend in-game currencies to improve them, and even then they are cappped at Lv 60, 110, and 160 unless you "evolve" them using character "Genes". Anyways, you'll need genes of other characters or "generic" genes to get them to a "breakthrough" point, and then you'll need the characters' genes to push them to the next evolution tier. This isn't just tedious, it's where the GACHA mechanic comes in. I won't go into it, but you have significantly lower odds of getting the genes of an "Angel" than any other. Oh, and you either need to save up 100 genes of a character to unlock them or randomly pull the character from the gacha mechanic. Just to be clear, I've been playing for a month, having logged in every day, and accumulated over 100 hours of play and still have seven "S" tier "Angel" characters that are locked.

Characters:
There's almost no balance to the various characters. Yes, higher tier characters are more powerful than lower tier characters, but there is only one "C" tier character, four "B" tier characters, and no "D" tier characters, despite there being a checkbox for "D" tier in "Gene Recycling". These characters can only be upgraded to Lv 60.

There are 17 "A" Tier characters and they far eclipse the lower tiers because they can be upgraded to Lv. 110, equip UAVs that provide stat boosts and special effects in combat, and have three different skills: an attack, special attack, and a support skill. Meanwhile, the lower tiers can only be upgraded to Lv 60, can't equip a UAV, and don't have an support skill. 

Still, the "A" Tier characters are quickly eclipsed by "Angels" or "S" tier (and above) characters because they have a second support skill for a total four skill, can equip "Elves" which give them an HP shield, extra stat boosts, and a boost to a stat while the shield is at least 80% full, and effectively don't have a level cap. Even among these "Angels" however, there are some that stand out as particularly useful to have in your six person party.

First, you must always have Maya in your party, as the game revolves around her. However, she is arguably the weakest character in your party for most of the time you'll be willing to play this game. You'll need to proceed through multiple story segments to unlock her memories and boost her effectiveness in battle. Until that time, she may actually be stuck at Lv 60 while the rest of your party are at Lv 110. She has 3 types of weapons, each of which have their own skills and stats, and will synergize with 6 different characters by altering their special attacks to have extra effects and damage. This is where any semblance of balance falls apart.

Second, you'll want to have two healers to have any hope of surving a fight with enemies at the same power level. There are two that you will absolutely want in your party: "Gentle Healing" and "Sakura Dancer". Gentle Healing has the ability to revive a single character per battle, and Sakura Dancer has the ability to remove adverse status effects from any character she heals.

Okay, so that's three slots taken right? Well, we're about to fill a fourth with "Raging Angel" who has the ability to increase the energy of two characters in her row by 2 or more when she uses her special attack. She also has a chance to increase the energy of the whole party by 1 when she uses her normal attack or dies. She's far, far, too useful in the row with your healers to not use.

So, that leaves two slots for all the other "Angels" right? Wrong. Becuase of the added affects of the synergizing with Maya you're absolutely going to want specific characters depending on which weapon Maya is using. 

You'll probably end up using the Scythe most often as it's ridiculously OP compared to the other weapons, being able to damage the entire front row, and the characters you can synergize with are also fairly powerful. You'll want "Time Gaurdian" who can stun the entire front row of the enemy team, and "Arcane Scholar", since when her turn comes will gain an extra point of energy and increase an allies energy by, and whom's synergized special will add 3 points of energy to herself and whoever she is in a column with. That means She will always have enough energy for her special after she uses her special the first time in combat and practically guaranteeing the character in front or behind her can do so as well. Combined with "Raging Angel" your party might never even approach running out of energy.

If you're using the Sniper, you'll want "Bounty Hunter", who can stun a column of enemies, and "Time Jumper", who can stun all the enemies.

If you're using the Katana, you'll want "Justice Blade" who can blind the entire front row, and either "Tenka Fubu" who can prevent the entire front row of enemies from gaining energy, or "Deadly Shadow", who can stun anyone she crits agaisnt.

As you can see, there's basically no balance among the charsters. Worse still, however, is the characters that you can only get by spending money. Every week or so there is an Event that offers an "UP Recruit" character. The game makes it seem like you can get them by spending a special limited time currency that drops during the event. Except the currency only drops during the first half of the event and the chances that you will accumulate enough of them to spend to redeem the event character without buying more of this currency approaches "divide by 0".
